Create a structured outline for a Hero's journey book titled "The Invisible Thread" which is categorized as fiction.
The book is written in US-English.

Description: Isa Mendoza-Weber, night-charge nurse in Strasbourg, has spent seven years translating love into milligrams and shift-swaps, raising her kids on FaceTime. Half a world away, Carolina "Caro" Mendoza-Kim, former Army linguist turned homeschool mom in Seoul’s Songpa district, measures safety in subway stops and security drills while her JAG husband serves yet another UN rotation. They haven’t spoken since a funeral blow-up over who got the locket and who got blamed.

Grandmother Sun-ja’s email lands at 3:07 a.m. Strasbourg time—subject line: 29th, nothing else. Attached: a JPEG of the sisters at age ten and twelve, arms linked in the now-abandoned DMZ peace garden that was Sun-ja’s lifelong project, plus GPS coordinates and a scanned deed last registered in Sun-ja’s name. The body reads only: Come before the 29th, or lose everything. 

Isa books the last seat on a Seoul-bound flight; Caro boards the eastbound KTX with the twins in tow. Each carries half of the gold locket that once held the deed’s microfilm. Between them lie 5,500 miles, a sudden Seoul blizzard, and a South Korean government notice that the garden will be razed for a new rail line—on the 29th at noon. 

Told in alternating, time-stamped chapters that close the physical gap in real time, The Invisible Thread is a 30,000-word contemporary novella about the forty-eight hours it takes to cross an ocean and a decade of silence. As Isa and Caro navigate airport quarantine lines, midnight K-pop buskers, and a single shared Uber that can’t fit their baggage—literal and emotional—they must decide whether the land that once anchored their family is worth the pain of facing each other, or if the only thing they’ll bury is the past itself.
